issue.title: Questions and comments on forecasting base classes and refactoring

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
I am trying to understand as much as possible before doing any actual refactoring.  Here are several comments/questions/suggestions. High chance I am mistaken or missing the point - if so, just say so!

1.  _base.py. the docstrings that an end-user will see are the docstrings in the BaseForecaster. E.g. for `fit`, they will see docstring containing `The base forecaster specifies the methods and method signatures that all forecasters have to implement.`
2. _base.py. `update_predict`
    1. What *is* `update_predict`? My guess is that it would be shorthand for `update` and then `predict` (similar to `fit_transform`). But this does not seem to be what is going on. Maybe it needs to be renamed.
    2. I think `cv` needs to be renamed. `cv` stands for cross validation, but I do not think there is any cross validation happening here.
    3. You raise a `NotImplementedError` if `return_pred_int`. I do not think we should have `NotImplementedError` in functions that will not be overwritten in children classes. In my head there are two options: have NotImplementedError in appropriate place in the children or simply not have `return_pred_int` as a parameter
    4. Currently, `update_predict` does input checks and then calls` _predict_moving_cutoff`. This is confusing; it does not look like any updating happens. Furthermore, it is different convention to other functions: `fit` calls `_fit`, `predict` calls `_predict`. Note that my confusion here is related to point 2.i about not knowing what update_predict is intended to do.
3. `score`. minor points only:
    1. change 'MAPE' to 'sMAPE' in first line of docstring
    2. maybe rename 'score' to 'sMAPE_score' or 'sMAPE'??
    3. where is this `score` method used?
4. `_get_y_pred` and `_get_pred_int`.
    1. using the name `get` makes it sound like the method is a getter method (as in setters and getters), but I don't think these are getter methods. I suggest renaming these
    2. the functions are hard to read. need to add some whitespace at least
    3. `_get_pred_int` is used in only place (according to my vscode search), namely _tbats. seems unusual that a helper function defined in base is used in only one place, but maybe there is intentions to use it more.
5. `_set_fh`. The very first if condition and error message seems incorrect to me. We have `if not requires_fh` in if condition and the error message says 'fh must be passed'. Presumably the rest of the if loops need to be checked; I have not checked them.

body:
maybe `update_predict_multiple` instead of `update_predict_playback`?

You are making multiple updates and predicts, and it pairs well with the method name `update_predict_single`

>and it pairs well with the method name `update_predict_single`

but the proposal includes the removal of `update_predict_single`.
Further, it should be clear through naming that multiple application is basically the key step in backtesting, i.e., you already need your entire data ready. "multiple" isn't so clear here.

> * `update` remains as is currently
> * `update_predict` becomes what `update_predict_single` is currently, a short-hand for "one `update` then one `predict`

I think we have discussed this before, I fully agree. 

> * current functionality in `update_predict` gets replaced by an `update_predict_playback`, as below.

* I prefer @Lovkush-A's suggestion: `update_predict_multiple` or `update_predict_cv` would perhaps be clearer still. 
* What's the thinking behind changing the signature from `cv` to `cutoffs`? Don't CV objects encode different sets of cutoffs? Note that there is a `CutoffSplitter` which you can pass a list of cutoffs and it will do what you suggest. 
* More generally, my preference is to remove this method entirely and instead rely on stand-alone functions like `evaluate` for backtesting. To me, the implementation inside the class isn't very straightforward and most users are more familiar with functions similar to `cross_val_predict` from scikit-learn. 

Note that we need to run deprecation cycle with user warnings before actually making the change.

* I think the change from `cv` to `cutoffs` is because the name `cv` itself is not the best name. `cv` sounds like cross-validation, which sounds like it is some kind of function/method.

* I am also in favour of just removing the `update_predict_playback` method entirely, and instead having cross validation as a separate function as part of validation toolbox. However, this preference is biased by not knowing anything about current state of validation in sktime, or the pros and cons of having method within forecaster objects versus method outside forecaster objects.
@Lovkush-A note that `cv` is used in scikit-learn as an argument name for cross-validation iterators (see e.g. the constructor of `GridSearchCV`) which is also what we pass here.

> @Lovkush-A note that `cv` is used in scikit-learn as an argument name for cross-validation iterators (see e.g. the constructor of `GridSearchCV`) which is also what we pass here.

Just checked the docs of sklearn. In my view, we should deviate from sklearn variable name choice in this instance, because I think it is significantly unclear.
@Lovkush-A I think most sktime users will be familiar with scikit-learn. What is unclear about, the suggestion in the name "cross-validation" that it's a function?  What would you call it?

@mloning 

> I think most sktime users will be familiar with scikit-learn.

Are most sktime users familiar enough with sklearn to know how `cv` is used in sklearn? I can only speak for myself and I did not know. I very well could be in the minority!

> What is unclear about, the suggestion in the name "cross-validation" that it's a function? What would you call it?

* To me, 'cv' sounds like it would be a function which carries out cross validation.
* Within GridSearchCV, I would prefer something like 'cv_strategy' or 'cv_type' or similar
* Within update_predict_playback (or whatever we will call it), my suggested alternative would depend on the possible values the `cv` variable can take. If the possible values are a list/series/index of times, then I prefer something like `cutoffs`.

issue.title: re-factoring existing forecasters to new interface

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
We need to slowly re-factor all forecasters to be compliant with the new interface (see PR #912). i.e., no overrides of `fit` etc and descendant classes only implementing core logic, while the `BaseForecaster` implements check etc logic.

Currently this is running due to various downwards compatibility workarounds, which should be removed once all forecasters are ready (in "no-override" state)

The forecasters that still need a downstream refactor are:
 * [x] `NaiveForecasters` #953
 * [x]  `EnsembleForecaster` #977
 * [x]  `MultiplexForecaster` #977
 * [x]  `TransformedTargetForecaster` #977
 * [x]  `_Reducer` and related code #1031
 * [x]  `StackingForecaster` #977
 * [x]  `ForecastingGridSearchCV`, `RandomizedGridSearchCV`, and `BaseGridSearch` #1034
 * [x]  `OnlineEnsembleForecaster` and descendants #1015
 * [x]  `_PmdArimaAdapter` and descendants `ARIMA`, `AutoARIMA` #1016 - adapter only
 * [x]  `BATS`, `TBATS`, and `_Tbatsadapter` #1017 adapter only
 * [x]  `_StatsModelAdapter` and descendants `AutoETS`, `ExponentialSmoothing`, `ThetaForecaster`  #1029
 * [x]  `HCrystalBallForecaster` #1004
 * [x]  `Prophet` and `_ProphetAdapter` #1005
 * [x]  `PolynomialTrendForecaster` #1003

For a how-to, useful resources are the forecaster extension template in `extension_templates` and PR #953 as an example for `NaiveForecaster`.

Based on discussions, we need to do the following two things in a capstone refactor that removes the last traces of the workarounds and goes over the above for consistency:
- [x] remove the `_SktimeForecaster` and mixins for good
- [ ] go through all forecasters and check the tags for correctness

issue.title: Implement Stlforecaster

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
<!--
Thanks for contributing a pull request! Please ensure you have taken a look
at our contribution guide: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

#### Reference Issues/PRs
<!--
Example: Fixes #1234. See also #3456.

Please use keywords (e.g., Fixes) to create link to the issues or pull requests
you resolved, so that they will automatically be closed when your pull request
is merged. See https://github.com/blog/1506-closing-issues-via-pull-requests
-->


#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
<!--
A clear and concise description of what you have implemented.
-->

#### Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one?

<!--
If your contribution does add a new hard dependency, we may suggest to initially develop your contribution in a separate companion package in https://github.com/sktime/ to keep external dependencies of the core sktime package to a minimum.
-->

#### What should a reviewer concentrate their feedback on?

<!-- This section is particularly useful if you have a pull request that is still in development. You can guide the reviews to focus on the parts that are ready for their comments. We suggest using bullets (indicated by * or -) and filled checkboxes [x] here -->

#### Any other comments?
<!--
Please be aware that we are a loose team of volunteers so patience is necessary; assistance handling other issues is very welcome. We value all user contributions, no matter how minor they are. If we are slow to review, either the pull request needs some benchmarking, tinkering, convincing, etc. or more likely the reviewers are simply busy. In either case, we ask for your understanding during the review process.
-->

#### PR checklist
<!--
Please go through the checklist below. Please feel free to remove points if they are not applicable.
-->

##### For all contributions
- [ ] I've added myself to the [list of contributors](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/.all-contributorsrc).
- [ ] Optionally, I've updated sktime's [CODEOWNERS](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/CODEOWNERS) to receive notifications about future changes to these files.
- [ ] I've added unit tests and made sure they pass locally.

##### For new estimators
- [ ] I've added the estimator to the online documentation.
- [ ] I've updated the existing example notebooks or provided a new one to showcase how my estimator works.


<!--
Thanks for contributing!
-->

body: I like `cv_strategy`, I agree it's clearer than just `cv`, but prefer not move away from scikit-learn.

@fkiraly @mloning. To summarise so far.

Things we agree on:
* agree on keeping `update`
* agree on renaming `update_predict_single` to `update_predict`, and have it correspond to "one update and then one predict"

Things we disagree on / that are not decided:
* Whether we keep a `update_predict_playback` method, or remove it as a forecaster method and replace it with something like `cross_val_predict`
* If we keep it, what the name of method should be.
* The name of `cv` variable
